page.syntax: Result_Flag as L = LIKE(C string_1,C Character_String_2)

argument.name: string_1
argument.description: A character string, can include the standard wildcard characters * and ? . * Represents any number of characters, including no characters at all. ? Represents a single character. You can use the wildcard characters more than once anywhere in Find_String.

argument.name: Character_String_2
argument.description: The character string to compare to string_1. Character

page.description: Returns TRUE if all or part of the first string is found in the second string.
page.discussion:
LIKE() returns .T. (TRUE) if Find_String equals Search_In_String ; otherwise, it returns .F. (FALSE). This function is extremely useful in filter expressions. It is more flexible than the $ operator because it enables you to search for the occurrence of one string at a specific location within another string. For example, the expression LIKE("super*computer*inc.", LOWER(COMPANY)) is TRUE for all company names that meet the following conditions:
Start with "Super"
Have the string "computer" anywhere within the name
End with "Inc."
The Find_String argument is case sensitive.
